article_title: Undocumented migrants: Obama asks the Supreme Court to act fast to save his immigration orders
article_text:
FIVE months ago, the Supreme Court turned back a challenge to the Affordable Care Act that would have scuttled Barack Obama’s signature legislative achievement. On November 21st, the president’s solicitor general, Donald Verrilli, asked the Supremes for another favour. Mr Verrilli urges the justices to step in to save Mr Obama’s immigration plan before the president bids farewell to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue on January 20th 2017.

The president announced the policy changes a year ago via a series of executive orders. Since Congress had failed to pass an immigration package, Mr Obama explained, he would do what he could within the boundaries of existing law to ease the plight of some of America’s 11m undocumented migrants. But Republicans cried foul. By unilaterally delaying the deportation of some 4.4m illegal immigrants, then-House Speaker John Boehner charged at the time, Mr Obama “cemented his legacy of lawlessness and squandered what little credibility he had left”. A conservative commentator said the executive actions—which would grant temporary relief to illegals who came to America as children and to parents whose children are American citizens and who have lived in the country since 2010—constituted an “impeachable offence”.

Mr Obama’s promise of leniency never got off the ground. Texas and 25 other Republican states immediately sued the administration for violating, among other things, the Administrative Procedure Act, a law the requires notice and public comment on policy changes before they are implemented. The district court ruled that Texas and the other states had “standing”, the legal right to sue the federal government, and that they were likely to prevail on their claims in a full trial. Earlier this month, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals agreed.

In his 35-page brief asking the justices to review the Fifth Circuit ruling, Mr Verrilli writes that the secretary of homeland security has “broad discretion” to decide who gets deported and when. While “[m]ore than 11m removable aliens are estimated to live in the United States”, the brief reads, “Congress has appropriated the funds to remove only a fraction of that population in any given year.” In fact, the government “has not been able to remove more than 4% of the estimated removable population in any year”.

Given these constraints, violent criminals have been at the top of the removal list while law-abiding people have been spared deportation. Mr Obama’s executive orders instruct the Department of Homeland Security to permit child immigrants and parents of American citizens to remain in the country legally and to breathe a bit more freely. The policy is meant as a humanitarian gesture to “hard-working people who have become integrated members of American society”. It is, the administration insists, in line with “this nation’s security and economic interests and make[s] common sense, because [it] encourage[s] these people to come out of the shadows, submit to background checks, pay fees, apply for work authorisation...and be counted.” Mr Obama’s actions do not, however, grant citizenship to anyone, and the deferred removal may be “revoke[d] at any time”.

Texas and the other states complain that these changes put them on the spot to provide driving licences, work permits and the like to millions of legalised illegals. By requiring states to issue these new benefits, they say, the administration imposes new burdens on states and violates principles of federalism. Mr Verrilli’s rejoinder is persuasive. While temporary legal status confers automatic federal benefits on these individuals, the states are under no obligation to provide any particular benefits of their own. Mr Obama’s orders do “not bar a state from eliminating [a] subsidy if it believes that federal policy choices no longer align with its interests”.

Time is of the essence: the administration must persuade the Supreme Court to hear the case by the end of January to get the case on the docket for the term ending next June. Otherwise, Mr Obama will leave office before the case is resolved. Lawyers in the Solicitor General’s office worked around the clock to submit the polished appeal a mere 11 days after the Fifth Circuit’s ruling on November 9th. “The decision warrants immediate review”, Mr Verrilli pleads. Without quick action, the lower court rulings “will force millions of people...to continue to work off the books, without the option of lawful employment to provide for their families. And it will place a cloud over the lives of hundreds of thousands of people who came to the United States as children [and] have lived here for years”. The Supreme Court should step in to avert a “far-reaching and irreparable humanitarian impact”.

Under court procedures, the states have 30 days to submit their response brief. But on Monday, Scott Keller, the solicitor general of Texas, wrote a note to the justices citing a litany of other work swamping the attorneys and requesting a 30-day extension. Mr Verrilli hopes the justices will not permit Texas and its red-state allies to tarry. “This court’s review,” he emphasises, “is warranted now".
